title: About ME
text: Hello my name is Emilie Chi! I am currently a sophomore at the University of Pennsylvania, and am majoring in Communications (Concentration: Data and Network Science) and minoring in Consumer Psychology. This blog will capture my exploration and experimentation of language Models in my ‘Stories from data: Programming for Data Journalism’ UPENN Clas

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


weather_df = pd.read_csv('data/philadelphia_weather_2005_to_2025.csv')
weather_df = weather_df.assign(date=pd.to_datetime(weather_df['date']))

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
section: A) What was the average fahrenheit for the day?
text:
A) What was the average fahrenheit for the day?

birthday = weather_df.query('day == "January 30"') 
temp_avg = (birthday['high'] + birthday['low'])/2
weather_df = weather_df.assign(temp_avg=(weather_df['high']+weather_df['low'])/2)


weather_df.query('day =="January 30"')

Since I was born in 2006, combining the weather data of Philadelphia for the past twenty years, the average fahrenheit on my birthday in Philadelphia is 32.3 degrees.

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
text:
B) Did it rain?

birthday = weather_df.query('day == "January 30"') 
is_rain = birthday['rain']>0


is_rain

29       True
394     False
759      True
1124     True
1490    False
1855     True
2220    False
2585    False
2951     True
3316    False
3681    False
4046    False
4412     True
4777     True
5142     True
5507    False
5873    False
6238    False
6603    False
6968    False
7334    False
Name: rain, dtype: bool



is_rain.value_counts()

rain
False    13
True      8
Name: count, dtype: int64



Since I was born in 2006, majority of the years since I was alive on the day of my birthday in Philadelphia it did not rain. (13 years it did not and 7 years it did).

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
text:
C) Did it snow?

birthday = weather_df.query('day == "January 30"') 
is_snow = birthday['snow']>0


is_snow.value_counts()

snow
False    14
True      7
Name: count, dtype: int64



Since I was born in 2006, majority of the years since I was alive on the day of my birthday in Philadelphia it did not snow. (14 years it did not and 6 years it did).

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
section: D) What day of the week was it?
text:
D) What day of the week was it?

weather_df.query('day == "January 30"') ['dow_name'].value_counts()

dow_name
Monday       4
Sunday       3
Tuesday      3
Wednesday    3
Saturday     3
Thursday     3
Friday       2
Name: count, dtype: int64



Since I was born in 2006, the largest amount of my birthdays have fallen on a Monday.

title: Dataset of the Week #1: The Weather in Philadelphia
text:
Conclusion
The weather in Philadelphia on the days of my birthday for the past twenty years was something I was curious about, especially to see if there was a pattern that I can relate back to myself. I found that majority of my birthdays fell on a Monday, it did snow nor rain for most of the years, and the avgerage temperature was 32 degrees on my birthdays put together. So overall, most of my birthdays throughout the years here in Philadelphia were not extremely cold, but still on the chillier side. I find that interesting, because I spent my recent birthday in 2026 freezing, because of how cold it was from the piled up snow from the previous snow storm and high winds. I thought this was the norm weather here in Philadelphia on Jan 30, but referencing past years’ data it shows otherwise. This was an interesting finding.
